job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Geneva, IL
pros: I feel like my direct supervisor and those above them actually care about me. They frequently ask us our opinions on things that they're considering implementing. They want our honest, anonymous input. The benefits are the best I've ever seen which include the typical medical/dental/vision but also a $250 a year credit toward wellness which you can use on massages, gym memberships, shoes for work, etc. The 401k match is unbeatable. They match 100% up to 6% plus an additional 50% for another 4%, fully vested in one year. You can tell they actually care about your work life balance and your mental health. They're also one of the only companies I've ever known to offer a shadow experience after an interview if they like you and are considering you. I was able to shadow on the unit for 2 hours and and got to meet the people I be working with and got a feel for the culture on the unit. That was a game changer. Knowing what you're walking into and being able to accept it or reject it was a great opportunity.
cons: Honestly can't think of any

pros: Great opportunities to learn, to gain skills for ultrasound guided IVs, tube feeding placement, research opportunities to build tour resume. Will encourage you to become certified.
cons:
Specific for Nortthwestern Memorial Hosptial-If you want to work in any Med/Surg or ER, you will end up working with the worst phlebotomists and the worst PCTs. Phlebotomists will refuse to do their job every single morning, even if it is their job. They will make excuses to not draw blood. Will get upset at you if you have any add on labs. Will not come to round on floor and RNs end up drawing them. 
PCTs are unionized, every other technician is unionized and will contact the union rep against you to try to get nurses they don’t like in trouble. PCTs always have an attitude. Absolutely no motive to work together. They will leave during the shift even when they are sitting for a suicidal patient. 
Management will not do anything for nurses even if you give them clear documentations. Transporters are extremely rude. They will interrupt you during shift change and yell at you for how long they have been waiting for a patient using the bathroom. Absolutely no respect for the patient whatsoever. Toxic work environment. Nurses get the short end of the stick. Pay was very low for what we did. Unless you are night shift, you will not make enough money for job satisfaction. Very high turnover rate.

review_title: RUN far away from NM. Work at Rush, UI Health, UChicago, or literally anywhere else.
pros: There are very few pros to working at NM. The working hours for non-clinical staff are pretty short (average 25-30 hours/week). There is a $250/year wellness reimbursement benefit that kicks in on Jan. 1 of each year. (Use it immediately!) There are some discounts for NM employees in the Streeterville area. Some of the colleagues and coworkers are nice, smart, and hard-working; but some are also toxic, gossipy, backstabbing, etc. There's a bonus of ~3-3.75% around the holidays (pro-rated if you start after Jan. 1 and not applicable if you start between June 1 and August 31) if you can stomach still working there when it pays out.
cons: I'm not exaggerating when I say that if I could give NM zero - or negative - stars, I would. First, the pay at NM is abysmal. They aren't ashamed of the fact that they are the lowest paying major hospital system in Chicago. They refuse to tell employees their comp ratio or give employees the full salary range for their position. They cry poor and claim that "[they're] a nonprofit" whenever you ask for a raise or market adjustment. There is NO bonus and NO raise for employees who start between June 1 and August 31 of each year. Second, the hospital system - especially the upper leadership - has a huge attitude problem. They heavily milk their current (but possibly not future) "#1 in Chicago and top 10 in the country" status to gaslight employees who raise complaints or make suggestions and expect employees to feel grateful for the "opportunity" and "privilege" to work there. They do not appreciate employees; everyone is replaceable and viewed just as a number. Even when we log into the systems, we are "nm" followed by a series of numbers. They do not care that employees are leaving in droves because they hate it there and management treats them like trash. The leadership from the directors on up is toxic. Tons of in-fighting and complete lack of focus and vision. Please do not work here. You deserve so much better. Rush, UChicago, and UI Health all treat their employees with respect and it shows in their salaries, benefits, and overall attitude. Plus, at least they scored higher than a "C" on the most recent Leapfrog assessment... makes you wonder how NM got the #1 spot in the first place...

job_title: Staff RN Medical/Surgical Floor in Palos Hills, IL
pros: A lot of the staff members, in various departments are genuinely amazing humans and make unbearable environments a little better.
cons:
Terrible management, complete disregard for patient safety, general safety (rt. Staffing, cleaning, resources/items provided for pts and basic necessities for staff to compete tasks). 

Instead of compensating fulltime staff more with a long teased pay increase mention, slapped us with 1% increase, less than or equal to 50¢ "promotion", while watching loyal staff quit in droves to be replaced by even more 3x hourly staff rates, and or floating staff who have now consistently been responsible for growing pt deaths. Staff are required to work every other weekends and expected to take min 6 pts/precept/train without incentive or notification.Expectations are to do nursing/CNA/wound care/ and PT ueless contract staffing that often illegally document care, and at times are abusive. 
Rooms, equipment, anything reusable is never cleaned appropriately or even at all (i.e. pt rooms often are "mopped" down with the same liquid that's been used by the last however many shifts, leaving gross smells and weird residual smearing, ignoring dangerous can accumulate on your furniture) none of the equipment works. If you find a rolling computer that will turn on, open epic, has a functional scanner, it probably will either randomly shutdown or can't connect to our internet when moved, especially more than 10 feet (or too quickly/accidental bump/try to plug in to charge). We've recently had some upgrades I guess for our garbage outdated IV Alaris pump equipment. They've places new colored stickers on them, still same charge/connection/function issues, but hey, there a new colored sticker? Our old phones were absolute trash, old school brick nokea, now have become a new wave soft edge nokea that worked very well for 2-3 months? To be fair, our phone reception connection doesn't disconnect or search for service mid call anymore, instead just won't allow you to hear the caller or speak to them, usually one or the other. Majority also have damage with microphone/speaker from what believe is caused by frequency of sanitization. The expenses northwest pays for epic access should make them ashamed enough to know that there's no efficient way to communicate with the healthcare team. There are plenty of ways to communicate with the healthcare team through epic, even implementing viscera communication devices, honestly smoke signals are seemly Better options for healthcare team communication. Northwestern apparently doesn't care that everyone other than doctors he has to waste hours of their life calling answer services over and over again, listening to the same 12 minute recording about hours of operation to even get to the beginning of the number selection to only "leave a message or page" for the Dr that 94% of the time will never call back until it's escalated to death certificate. It's hands up best situations when the doctor forces to me confidence that of course we need to call and the consults verbally insult us for calling and refuse to take the patient/or when looking for discharge papers all the drs go back and forth blaming each other needing auth from the other, refusing to call themselves even though they obviously have each other's direct lines and us peeons are only allowed to play phone tag while keeping pts stable/trying to prevent being kicked in the face AGAIN, Drs lie to pts about leaving or make promises without followup always. Pts complain, and it's your fault. Have spent too many hrs of reporting concerns/inappropriate hcp access, literally documenting how attendings we're notified hrs , days sometimes weeks about how the pt they're caring for on call is actively dying and they're allowing it due to irresponsibly. Complaints about the absolute lack of physician communications is aonly applicable during the shift operator managers hrs that day. Often it's better/quicker to request a different physician team for critical pt situations. It's disgusting and absolutely unacceptable , especially that clinicians are allowed to consult the same unavailable groups of physicians, causing more concern, should not be allowed .
We have zero equipment. No wound care equipment foams, (zero ostomy equipment as opposed to our almost nothing stock), no dietary basics like spoons, applesauce, anything diabetic friendly, bedside equipment, cares and comfort/safety- contact gowns, fitted sheets, blankets, pt gowns, viable gloves. How disgusting is it to gown up in something supposed to be sanitized and protect you that has wet sleeves and sticky residual adhesive throughout. How about when you're told you have a serious contact droplet pt but don't have a fit mask or eye protection. Embarrassingly have to bring multiple sheets/blankets general bedding to pts bc all the first ones have disgusting things still attached or stained.

I've been waiting for northwestern to make things better and honestly things have only gotten more difficult,more frustrating, forcing out good employees that should be a priority for retention. Need experienced staff to train new hires, since management is absolutely clueless rt pt care. Nurse manager and nursing educator walked off understaffed floor bc of feeling uncomfortable/unknowledgeable, especially after educator accidentally drew up letal doses of insulin after giving the team a presentation rt insulin and it's importance in diabetics. 

I wish I could make this up.

review_title: Good Hospital, Training/Orientation Not Up To Par For New Grads
pros: Best part of job is co-workers, department manager, team work. I work in ICU, and feel it is a very autonomous setting.  Northwestern is one of the best in the country, and this seems to help in opening doors when you have it listed on your resume. They also get a lot of complex patients from outside hospitals, so there are opportunities to learn and grow as a nurse within the department if you're motivated.
cons: Biggest challenge is lack of orientation. On average, a couple of weeks (2-3 shifts per week) and then you're thrown in and told if you have questions that the nurses around you will assist/mentor. I don't feel that this is appropriate training even on a Med-Surg floor, never mind in an ICU setting. They hire many new grads who do not have the "hands on" experience needed to be successful without a more comprehensive orientation. This makes for a frustrating work environment for both new staff as well as experienced nurses who are expected to fill in the gaps.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in South San Francisco, CA
pros: PTO / Vacation, Benefits, Holiday Bonus
cons: Pay scale not universal across the board.  Due to the merging of NMG, NMPG, NMFF the same position salary differed. I had a degree and many years customer relations and a co-worker (same title) with zero business experience and no higher education was hired in at $2.00/hr more that I. After the merge they compensated the employees with the lower wages. My compensation was $0.07/hr with 2 years more experience in the position than my colleague. When I approached the Practice Manager with this information, she said "I is against NW policy to discuss your salary with co-worker" little did she know that it is against the law to for a company to put in place such a policy. This is your personal business and you are free to discuss your personal business. The company however is not able to share that information with other employees. $2.00/hr is life changing...that is $4160.00/yr  X 2yrs= $8320.00!!!!! Not OK!

pros: Opportunities, decent pay, decent benefits
cons: Lots of politics, very few women in leadership

review_title: Low Morale and High Turnover makes for a Chaotic Career
pros: The campus is shiny, beautiful and relatively new, located right off the hustle bustle of Michigan Ave. While working for an inpatient ancillary department, I gained lots of experience working as a new grad with a variety of patient populations from all walks of life. They provide great benefits, competitive 401k match, and business discounts for NMH employees. Getting overtime was never a problem.
cons: Management here has been constantly changing ever since I was first hired. Everything was consolidated with one manager overseeing a bunch of ancillary departments. They are suits spewing optimistic managerial talk of "innovative restructuring" while staff suffer the burdens of taking on more work with less support. This means high turnover which means having to take on dangerously high assignment loads. With management changes, had to define my job responsibilities to the everchanging faces at my annual reviews. Despite going above and beyond during chaotic times, felt like I was always given the standard merit increase.

pros: Quickly growing organization with numerous acquisitions in the last 2 years.  Plenty of employment opportunities.
cons:
Too many managers and not enough analysts to actually do the work.  Many of the managers are unqualified for managing staff and lack the skills and knowledge to support their role.  Duplicate efforts, unproductive meetings, lack of direction, poor leadership, and  wasted time are common themes for the IS department.  Inflexible and inconsistent work from home policy. The role of an analyst is much like a scavenger hunt, in that there are no direct resources and managers lack the knowledge to guide in the right direction.  

The organization is seniority based and not merit based.  There are layers of management.  The manager that gives your review does not work directly with you and is not familiar with your work. 

Managers can be unprofessional and show favoritism.   There is a culture of hiring children of senior leadership that lack the skills and experience for the roles they fill.

pros: PTO is fair and offered benefits are great. Work location and hours are ideal to balancing life with kids. Easy to take needed time off for planned or unplanned family events.
cons: It's hard to advance or move out positions. The ever changing organization makes it difficult to feel secure in a job. The pay raises are insufficient with the cost of living. Not all managers have the same standards making it difficult to deal with each of them.  HR is way too involved when it comes to compensating employees and title changes. For example, if you have a certain title your rate of pay is based on that, so even if you do twice as much work and support twice as many people you won't be paid more based on your abilities. Too much nepotism.

review_title: Bottom Line $$ is the only thing that matters to Administration
pros: Pay for administration is fair. Research is robust and valued.
cons: Administration does not value their employees - they think only bigger paychecks and 401K matching is what matters to people who work in healthcare. Sure it is a driver, but being a valued part of the team, mentorship, and really taking care of patients/people are all overlooked. The culture is stressful and you need to have 10 meetings for simple tasks because the bureaucratic nature stymies creativity and actually putting patients first.  The "benefit" they give you for higher education is a joke, they barely give you money (even when you attend Northwestern University) to further your own education and growth. This is a boys club of who knows who, where you are kept safe if you make friends with the right people, they don't take in your work contribution at all.

review_title: NMH Puts CEOs Compensation Package Ahead of Quality Healthcare
pros: It was convenient in terms of transportation. The pay was average with raises begrudgingly given. A lot of money was spent to increase the real estate value of the hospital so it was a clean and modern work place.
cons: The focus of providing quality healthcare shifted over the course of the 15 yeas I worked there. NMH has become more interested in accumulating real estate to heft the pay and benefits of the executives who do not possess medical degress, but rather MBAs. This drive to increase the financial portfolio did not translate into better pay and benefits for staff, but rather put a squeeze on staff limits, having less patient care staff covering more patients. Benefits were whittled away for the majority of staffing positions.

review_title: It was once a great organization to work for
pros: Good Benefits and great location and culture (downtown only). Started here at the cusp of cultural change after few acquisitions/mergers. Had the benefit of experiencing the residue of what NM was originally based on: career development, transparency in information and management, talent retention and team building.
cons: What is left is bureaucracy, mediocre middle management that hides behind methodologies and rules, instead of applying actual work and acknowledging each team member's unique circumstance & talents. Majority of good talents have left and if work life balance seems notoriously unbalanced, it is because of the inexperienced management that is in place. With the acquisition, there are certain ideas and people that are promoted as the gold standard of talent & performance which has deteriorated the talent pool.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Winfield, IL
pros: 403B.   My peer nurses are exceptional.   We care about our work, we care about the patients.    Majority of physicians are a pleasure to work with.
cons: Ratios of nurses to patients.   3:1 and 4:1 in ICU!   1:1's are now 2:1's despite policy.   It's extremely unsafe at times, both for the patients and staff.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Darlington, North East England, England
pros: Beautiful, clean, well-maintained hospital. Average age of nurses employed tends to be younger, in their 20s-30s. Many nurses are continuing their education and in school for CRNAs or Nurse Practitioner, so the nurses are very smart. Great co-workers.
cons: Lowest paying hospital in Chicago. Nurses have very little room for raises. Huge cutbacks with regard to orientation period for new nurses: no matter your experience you only have a 3 week orientation. High nurse turnover. Constantly changing managerial model. I now have 5 different managers, and have no idea who they are and vice versa. NMH spends all their money on making the hospital beautiful, but does not compensate their hardworking nurses accordingly.

review_title: I don't really want to leave this company, but...
job_title: Financial Analyst in Slough, Berkshire, South East England, England
pros: I love Northwestern, and it's a great company to work at. However, if you're unlucky and work with supervisors/managers that do not have the best interests in your career growth, you may get burn out and discouraged. Make sure that you try to network as much as possible, and get yourself known.
cons: Salaries discrepancies have discouraged me from wanting to work here forever

job_title: Labor and Delivery RN in Chicago, IL
pros: Working for such a well known hospital is great for your resume and they love hiring new grads. There are also many practice policies and procedures in place that help to guide safe and effective care of patients. My coworkers are incredible strong, intelligent people that all work very well together as a team.
cons: Hourly pay is much lower than most hospitals in the are for RNs. The leadership does not seem to care much about the nurses they work for and rules for scheduling, etc are ridiculously complicated and overly strict. Management can often be condescending on my unit, and I have heard my manager tell employees that we are easily replaced because the unit receives hundreds of applications a month. It is also fairly difficult to get reimbursed for continuing education and there is not a lot of encouragement to make nursing a career rather than just a job you go to.

review_title: Not a great place to be a nurse
pros: Great 401 matching program, good but expensive benefits, stable employment.
cons: NMH pays very poorly, doesn’t respect nor value their nurses, and will tell you that it is a “privilege to work at NMH”.  Most of the nurses in the ICU’s and floors are new with little experience as experienced RN’s typically won’t work here. They force you to come in early and stay late.  At least once a week I will put in 13+ hour day with only 45 minute lunch break, nothing else.  There is no respect for your well being or mental state. Patient safety is not a priority- profits are.  Chronically short staffed in most every area of the hospital.  Planning on leaving (as are most of my colleagues) once the right opportunity comes up.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Deerfield, IL
pros: The benefits are good. Tuition reimbursement was helpful although other organizations gave more. Good that they are an organization so you can find the specialty that best suits your needs by transferring.
cons: They take complete advantage of their employees. They allow stressful working conditions to linger if it means they save money. They will not do what it takes to keep a good employee to keep an office running well and stable. Their precious model is more important. But what the fail to realized or they realize but don't care is that the model doesn't fit for every specialty. They want everything cookie cutter. Except the pay completely unfair. 3 dollar hourly difference with similar work experience in the same office! If they can under sell you they will!

pros:
I think I was lucky, the department I worked in had great management and we were a great team. My coworkers became like family after a few years. 
The benefits were incredible. I had a minor surgery which cost me probably around $30 plus another $30 for scrip co-pays. 
Plenty of vacation time and sick/personal days. There was plenty of overtime when I needed it as well. 
I started with very little experience and NMH paid for me to take all kinds of courses and classes. 
Yearly review always came with a raise. Not a huge one, but at least it was something.
cons:
Unfortunately my position was dissolved. One woman in our office had been there over 30 years and her position was dissolved as well. 
I honestly can't think of too many bad things about working there. I would go back in a heartbeat if I could work the same office with the same people.

pros: Fairly decent pay, great health insurance
cons: Attendance policy is insanely strict (you're late if you come in 1 minute late or leave 1 minute early), Management is slow to implement new policies to make workflow easier and more fluid for the techs. When questioned about policies, they respond with defensiveness. Although pay is decent, pay is still on the low end for a medical technologist for sheer amount of samples you'll be processing and responsible for. Cost of living adjustment was a joke, 3% for everyone.

review_title: Don't work on special projects, you will get laid off
pros: Great benefits, laid back but intense atmosphere, nice offices
cons: Very flat organization, 20 people reporting to one manager.  They also laid off about half the IT team they hired for Project One (conversion to Epic).  We worked 50-60 hour weeks, weekends and then some and got one months severance with absolutely no effort to find new jobs for severed employees.

pros: I have always felt listened to by management. My manager is kind and receptive and they allow for growth for their nurses. They listened to us about changing patient ratios and it has helped us tremendously.
cons: Low pay. Can’t afford to work anything but nights.. this hospital is also very focused on the doctors and not on creating autonomous nurses. Turnover of RNs is so high on my floor that everyone is kind of new.. Lots of dumb mistakes being made by new grads. And for some reason, a lot of the staff are rude at this hospital.

review_title: Research Technologist II at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine

-Collaborative environment

-There's a lot of politics within departments and labs, so there is alot of drama which people supposedly thrive on

review_title: A lot of great opportunities to move within the company.
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Elgin, IL
pros: The insurance is great, leadership is approachable.
cons: The lack of human resources on site. Everything is located downtown, so if you have an immediate issue, you contact your nursing supervisor.  The nursing supervisors are usually overworked and swamped so some things gets left at the wayside.  You just need to advocate for yourself and reach out utilizing the tools the company has set up.  If you're not good at being your own advocate, this wouldn't be the place for you. The resources are there, you just have to figure it all out individually.

pros:
Great Benefits- the healthcare benefits there can't be beat
Amazing location- off of Michicagn avenue in downtown chicago
Competitive salaries
Room for growth- its a large company
cons:
Doctors who look down on other employees and treat them in a condescending manner
There different entities under one roof (NMH, Northwestern University and NMFF) makes everything much more difficult

pros: Great benefits, great patient care. Employees that want to work hard!
cons: Management has created a toxic work environment. You cannot give feedback for fear of retribution. Management is constantly paranoid and looking for a bad egg in the group. Talent Acquisition Managers say one thing and do another, and never listen to employee feedback.  Constantly understaffed with high workloads, little to no support from management, they listen but can’t offer solutions.  Positive change here never happens. Employees beg to work from home to avoid the toxic, unproductive work environment. Management will not fill open positions, and so employees are overworked.

job_title: Respiratory Care Practitioner in Aurora, IL
pros:
I loved working at Central DuPage Hospital. 
Staff was  great to work with. 
I enjoyed what I did for my patients. 
Excellent benefits.
cons: Apparently peer reviews don't account for anything. One could be loved and appreciated by staff, patients, and family.......that is not taken into account when one has health issues which affect attendance. Unless you've put in for an FMLA,, your job is not protected. No unemployment compensation when terminated because the company refuses to allow it.

review_title: It's a new fiscal year, must be time for layoffs...
pros: Very experience and intelligent staff; exposure to interesting cases and learning opportunities.  Lovely Streeterville location easily accessible by public transportation.  Healthcare benefits package is top notch.
cons: Management consumed by the bottom line and cost cutting.  Paid time off benefits package is not great, especially for a full-time exempt employee.  Few to no opportunities for advancement into management if you are not a registered nurse.

pros:
I came here as a recent college grad trying to get my foot in the door.
- As an admin assistant, you're essentially a glorified secretary but people really do appreciate what you do if you work hard.
- Relatively easy to move around the company if you have a degree/drive.
- Benefits are great
cons:
- If you don't have any clinical experience it will be more difficult to move up the ladder
- Pay increases are very minimal from year to year
- Depending on the department you work on, expect some drama/politics.
- If you don't like to be patient facing this is NOT the position for you.

review_title: Great place to start your career
job_title: Applications Analyst Senior in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits are pricey but very comprehensive if you stay within NM. Working in IT I had access to some exciting technology. You will never be bored as there are plenty of projects.
cons: Poor management. Often seem to make their plan up on the spot. No forward vision or planning.  Cares more about risk management than problem prevention. Too much red tape and too many procedural processes that inhibit staff ability to actually help clinical staff. Promotions appear to be based on nepotism. Management does not support all of their employees.

pros: Nice facilities, well marketed reputation. Nice art on the walls. Comfortable setting for patients.
cons: Administration is dishonest. Payment is not tracked well which opens up opportunity for skimming which is not an isolated event. Quality measures lacking and due soley to administrative decision or lack there of, care of patients are directly affected, interfering with appropriate and timely care but creation bureaucratic storms that impede proper patient care

review_title: Great Place to Work But Find a Mentor
pros: It's a wonderful opportunity to work at a place where incredibly smart people (doctors and nurses and all employees) are trying to make the lives of people better every day. NMH is a big, far flung campus. As a Writer and Editor, there was no shortage of stories to cover on the campus. We were also involved in crisis communications and providing communications expertise to internal clients, including executive management.
cons: It's a huge, complex organization. Find a mentor or someone to help you navigate the complexities and you'll be much better off. If you're not politically savvy you'll have a really difficult time here.

review_title: There’s pros and cons....read the fine print
pros: Student loan reimbursement, great (but expensive) insurance, health and wellness fund
cons: Management and upper management sees nurses as the only clinical employee held responsible. As nurses we are pcts, dietary, secretary, housekeeping, phlebotomy and so much more. Nurses are held to the highest of standards while pct and other clinical staff can refuse patient care with no consequence. Safe ratios are nonexistent and always above ratio on EVERY shift. Pcts are union and have different rules than nursing staff. Not to mention sick time, personal, and vacation are all in one PTO bank and the policies on attendance and PTO usage are unreasonable.

pros: Most processes are in place, it is very easy to come in and start working on projects, (you can hit the ground running). Management makes them self available to the employees and will assist in removing any hurdles. Over all it is a great place to work for.
cons:
The Hospital location makes it very costly to get to work. Parking is over 150.00 per month.
You can take public transportation but the cost of the train and bus adds up as well.
Very political, you will do great as long as you follow the procedures that are in place.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: Great health insurance, professional management and communication, thorough training, "patients first" manta upheld, highly respected company
cons:
No sick or vacation days- PTO is deducted for any absence, no matter what the cause. This forced employees who are ill to come to work if they don't have enough PTO, causing the spread of illnesses within the workplace.

It is nearly impossible to have your voice heard by management. Any requests or even feedback takes years to be addressed, if it is addressed at all.

review_title: Constant  micro managing, unfair expectations and no involvement in management attempting to make a comfortable environm
pros: The high level of professionalism amongst peers, feeling of working with a large family, benefits are excellent, the location is very nice
cons: Red tape, politics, no trust, constant looking over your shoulder and feeling as if you can never do anything right. NO TRUST

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Chicago, IL
pros: The staff at NM in the OBGYN department is incredibly friendly, helpful, and enjoyable to work with. The benefits are fantastic and the pay is totally fair.
cons: The job description for the position I was hired for was non-standard, and I felt like an island and not a part of the team for most of the time. This experience, due to the nature of my position, might not match the experience for most AAs. While most people in the department worked in close proximity to many coworkers, my desk was separate and I was often alone.

review_title: Overall company is great, locations vary
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Geneva, IL
pros: The benefits are competitive to other medical groups in the area, good life-work balance, company with amazing reputation. The company as a whole cares about its employees.
cons: Benefits are awesome, pay is not. There is a huge gap in pay depending on what office you work in, favoritism, how desperate they are to keep you, etc. At my location there was a huge turn over rate. Terrible management, it was absolutely awful. Low morale and no one did anything about it. Concerns and issues were dismissed and never addressed.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: Fast hiring because their so desparate...
cons: Well, they ride their employees like pack animals. If your on a break, nursing staff will not hesitate to come and ask for you to end your break early and offer all the guilt they can when you say no to them. And they are super anal when it comes to the patient privacy thing--an EKG trainer was reviewing a case with us in the hallway and one of their bureaucrats walked by and chewed out the trainer for possible patient privacy violations. So the people who are honestly paid to just think up new rules are firmly in control to justify their own continued jobs.

review_title: Honestly not worth traveling into downtown to work here
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: When I started working here 5 years ago I thought I had finally made it (after applying nonstop for 3 years to no avail). After making 16$ an hr at other hospitals I thought making $18.60+ $1.00 shift diff (for evenings) +$1.50 shift diff (for weekends) was great. They have tuition reimbursement, you get discount for certain things because of ur affiliation with NM. $250 reimbursement towards any purchases you have made to improve your health. Get to work at one of the number one hospitals in Illinois. Looks good for school and on future applications to other healthcare companies.
cons: Unnecessary exposures to health hazards. They do not enforce proper isolation protocols. I caught Covid on my unit, reported it the same day. I was off work an entire month, and the entire time I was off , trying to regain my strength and health, I had to fight with management and hr to put in for my workers compensation. Management will act like they did it (which is against the law) then play like u got denied. They no longer provide the 6% 401k match. They froze people’s 401ks when Covid started effecting the stock market so people couldn’t do an emergency withdraw to support their families. A lot of good nurses on my unit, but I have worked the medicine floors and the nurses are horrible. No help whatsoever. Tech work seems beneath them. Anyone making over 37/hr no longer can accrue pto. Parking in the garage that’s an ENTIRE BLOCK AWAY costs 130$/ month. Union does NOTHING. They take 60 something dollars out of ur check EVERY two weeks and wont fight for us. If u are not knowledgeable of labor laws or your union agreement your managers will use it against you. Before working at northwestern I was great, after almost 5 years of accidental exposures and nothing being done by management, I am now seeking psychiatric treatment for panick attacks and anxiety due to my job. I’m literally taking psychiatric medication now. I AM ONLY A PCT!!! Also, if you are going to work as a transporter or environmental services, BEWARE...managers will micromanage you to death! If you get reported on, for any little thing, they almost always go with the nurse or drs side. I had a coworker that got written up because a nurse emailed on her for standing at a desk because her rooms where done!

job_title: Clinical Nurse-Surgical Services in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent benefits, 6% 401k matching, excellent health insurance. Long orientation process.
cons: Even though the orientation process is long, if short staffed, you will be on your own in the middle of your orientation period. Nurses are overworked and under appreciated. Because of this, there is a very high nursing turnover rate. Instead of worrying about why that may be, they are always hiring. I have worked here for a year and a half and my unit has never been fully staffed. We have had five nurses leave and only replaced two in my short time here. There is also no real job advancement opportunities.

review_title: Great Attention to Capital Resources, Human Resources Are a Low Priority
pros: Salary tends to be mid to high range, great medical benefits, great location, convenient to mass transportation and shopping. Decent yearly bonuses for employees. Healthcare is a very stable and growing industry.
cons: Capricious, inconsistent, unstable management. Employees with long tenures were cut loose to save money. They are expanding too fast without a clear idea of how to manage it all and where they're heading (at least that's how it seems from an employee's perspective).

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Geneva, IL
pros: The staff and coworkers are informative and helpful.  You feel like you help people everyday and it's a fast paced environment.  The job is also active, you work on your feet most if not all day.
cons: The standards set at the company are extremely rigid and they expect too much with too little training. They did not properly prepare me and inform me of what is expected of me

review_title: No Upward Movement & Burn Out Quickly
job_title: Talent Acquisition Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Ability to work for the leading health systems in Illinois.
cons: Recent management changes has created a toxic work environment. There is no upward movement in this position. Promises of movement only to be told it will be talked about at a later date, and nothing has come of it. The same goes for work/home life balance of increasing work from home opportunities (remote), it has been discussed and no real action has followed, after repeated VOCAL request during every other meeting. They want you to give your best, but you are not getting the best from management. The Northwestern name is no longer a sticking point for employees to stay on this team. There are better opportunities for growth and expansion in other companies. Many people are CURRENTLY looking to leave, the 3-4 years seems to be burn out point for this team. Employees cannot give honest feedback regarding workloads, employee engagement, and overall work environments without being labeled a troublemaker or difficult. The culture of team is divided into many little clichés and tend to be harmful to the diversity and inclusion of the work environment. Management is not listening to their employees and will keep losing employees to other departments or more cohesive work environments outside of Northwestern.

pros: The experience gained at Northwestern is invaluable.  I am told it is a great resume booster.  You get to see a wide variety of cases on a daily basis.
cons: The pay is much lower than every other academic hospital in Chicago.  The PCTs we work with are very lazy and since they're union they can get away with it.  Staffing is always an issue and sometimes work loads feel unsafe.

review_title: Strong name recognition, unhealthy work culture.
pros:
1) Collaborative physicians; great learning experience.
2) Wealthy corporation with fancy hospitals and latest treatments; money to support good IT.
3) Good health insurance.
cons:
1) Not-for-profit hospitals/clinics that seem to prioritize profits over patient care and needs; too much focus on rankings.

2) Unhealthy, highly political work culture. Too hierarchical + discord between administration and physicians. Lots of employee turnover. Uninspiring upper management.

3)  Education reimbusrement isn't competitive. Only $5500 in education reimbursement (versus UofChicago Hospital, which provides 50% tuition at it's University).

job_title: Patient Financial Specialist in Winfield, IL
pros: I love working for Northwestern Medicine!  The culture is inviting and positive and they like to promote from within.  If you are ready for a change, there are always opportunities to change positions and try something new.  Compensation is mediocre, but is made up for in benefits.
cons: The interviewing and overall hiring process takes a while and can be frustrating for new hires.  Also the pay scales could be adjusted, there are several positions that are grossly underpaid.  There have also been many times where the department I work for has been severely under staffed.

review_title: Good company, bad department, some good teams
pros: The pay is respectable for the kind of work that the teams do.  The overall benefits package has improved over the last few years.
cons: Work-life balance is skewed towards work a little too much. Off-hours support is needed from most every team. Hard work will get you to senior and lead titles, cutthroat office politics are required to break through to management.

pros: Excellent reputation, Diverse patient population, Excellent health insurance, close to public transportation, access to residents around the clock
cons: Poor pay, poor management, ineffective training for new nurses, parking is $130+/month, hospital area not clean, heavy patient load, nurse floated to various departments without proper training, Managers do not engage with staff, poor advocacy for nurses

pros: Close to home, variety of work to do, management has many staff outings to boost morale and listens to employees.  Good team work.  Got to attend seminars and work with latest technology.  Training courses were sometimes provided.
cons: Most project handled by outside contractors, staff mostly does support.  Contractors were supposed to be phased out.  As a result it was hard to get a promotion.  Contractors would miss steps and staff would have to come back and correct mistakes.  Spending went down after merger with Cadence Health.

job_title: Help Desk Support in Chicago, IL
pros: Everyone is friendly. Co-workers and supervisors will help you out and they are very nice to talk to. Even joke with you, makes you feel like you can belong there.
cons: There's some strict rules. As a full-time you do not want to be late. I heard few people got fired before I came in as a contractor and another fulltime staff was fired my 3rd week. She was the nicest person, personality wise, that worked there and she was fired.

pros: It used to be salary and benefits. Now it is just salaries, they do pay better than other hospitals. But the raises are pitiful and benefits have been cut tremendously.
cons: Micro Dpt has terrible management, afraid to move forward with innovations. Age discrimination. They favor younger workers and males. Not able to schedule vacation when needed. Even though NMH sells itself as a great place for working mothers, it is not. A lot of resentment against married women since most of management in the lab are single women.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Lake Forest, IL
pros: Amazing coworkers, doctors, and patients. I learned so much in this position and was working on my own without a in office manager for a couple years.
cons: The yearly pay increases were so minimal it was offensive. No acknowledgement to the employees that deserve it, but very quick to acknowledge small errors.

review_title: Widespread morale problem for all but C-suite
pros: Attracts excellent talent, great location
cons: While the CEO shows off his new private boardroom and lounge in the newest pavilion, department and hospital leaders are being fired or are quitting. Rumor has it that several nurses were fired for getting coffee while not on official break.The environment has become toxic. It is clear that pointing out areas for improvement are interpreted as insurgence and being treated as such.

pros: This is a 24/7 position so there are lots of hours to fill. No face to face contact with public. Downtime between calls is nice. Nice co-workers and atmosphere. Get to help people without being a medical professional.
cons: Answering service to a couple hundred doctor's offices also - doctors can be very demanding. Must respond efficiently and correctly to a range of emergency codes. Not much room for advancement.

review_title: Good work experience in a field I never thought I'd be in.
pros: Good benefits, excellent institutional reputation, decent compensation. Time-off/PTO accrual allowed for a quick buildup of days to take off. Easy commute to work with access to public transportation.
cons: Sometimes asked to spin straw into gold. Senior leadership didn't always grasp lack of communication between departments when brought to their attention. There are not always smooth ways to move up within the organization.

pros: I started out as a temp at Northwestern Medicine and I thoroughly enjoyed the team I worked with. Staff level/contributors have a vested interest in the care of their patients and families. Nurses, Social Workers alike, put the patient first.
cons:
Nurses, Social Workers alike, put the patient first, however, are often challenged (too often) with management’s decisions to cut corners in order to make a profit.
My job description as a temp was nowhere near the same job description which was offered to me when offered a permanent position.  The temp agency was absent during the transition from temp to perm (they were non-responsive to emails and calls; more interested in the end result and $ they receive when I was placed as a permanent employee).
Being up front with my manager about my career and expectations in the role had backfired. He was more focused on the business, conferences and his reputation within Northwestern as a marketing manager within the niche department.  He was uneasy with being faced with yet “another task” in terms of development of his staff.
When the opportunity presented itself to move into a role outside of Northwestern, I disclosed my decision to leave (presented a formal, written 2 week notice) and was met with extreme pushback from my manager.  Instead of being supportive and collaborating with me for the remainder of my tenure, he questioned (often) the validity of the opportunity, argued with me (multiple times) that I did not provide a 2 week notice, attempted to strong-arm me (daily) into changing my last day and made the last two weeks, very uncomfortable for me.  Contacting HR was pointless; they took my name and number and stated someone would get back to me, which never happened.

pros:
1. Great retirement benefits....if you qualify for them. (Good chance you wont.)
2. Library resources are pretty good. 
3. Very fancy (expensive) restaurants - they closed the cafeteria (and fired many long-term employees) and renovated to rent the space to fast-food restaurants. The food is tasty, but its expensive and very high in fat and sodium.
cons:
1. There are several different organizations all with different benefits and pay structures. Do NOT assume the NMH benefits are the ones you will qualify for. Residents and Fellows are McGaw employees and do not qualify for childcare grants and have very limited retirement benefits. Post-docs receive even worse benefits (no retirement, very limited health insurance where family coverage is not subsidized at all by Northwestern.)
2. Very corporate. Clearly money comes first. Then patients. Then employees. 
3. You will be used. You will be told anything they can to get you do what they want. You might jump through every hoop and excel. But that job you were promised (which is why you stayed) will not be there in the end. They will try to tell you its your fault and you did not do a good enough job jumping through one of the hoops. But we all know that even if you had, the job would not have been there anyway. 
4. Very limited office spaces. 
5. My car got banged up in the parking lot. I have more dings and scratches on my car after 9 months of driving than I had in the prior 15 years. I tried to switch parking garages but was told I wasnt allowed to change.

review_title: Great place to work, but can be improved
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: Great resume builder, excellent clinical teams, patient-centered work experience
cons: Not enough direction from upper-level administrative management, department direction very unclear or undefined, somewhat retaliatory reactions from management toward employees when asking for direction/assistance with job functions or proposing process improvements, management prevents/discourages current employees from advancing or growing within the organization

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros:
The company is amazing to work for. They offer some pretty great benefits and everyone I have met in my three years of being here has been super nice. It is a top notch hospital and I would recommend it to anyone. 

They offer a bonus to all employees in the month of November and it is based on a  certain percentage (changes every year) of your income up to that point. In other words, the more hours you work throughout the year, the greater your bonus will be. 

As a Patient Care Technician there is ALWAYS need! So you can pick up on any floor aside from yours as long as you do not exceed 60 hours/ wk.  I am part time (24 hrs/ wk), however, I always work the full time hours by simply doing doubles three days/wk.  

Honestly, one of the best companies I have worked for as a PCT.
cons: The only Cons I have to say about this company is that they do not offer much for tuition reimbursement, what they do offer is very little. Additionally, they do not pay based on level of education. For example, nurses who have masters degrees make the same as those with bachelors. I recently received my masters and decided to apply within the company for a position in my field of study. I went for an interview but did not get the job offer because my current pay was greater than the one for the masters degree position. The current job that I hold right now only requires a high school diploma and recommend a bachelors degree. The shifts are also only 8 hours for PCTs as opposed to 12 hours.

job_title: Medical Records Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Very easy job. Relaxed work environment.
cons: Repetitive. Pretty much factory line work in an office setting. Unsustainable for someone living in Chicago. $13 an hour for someone with a college degree and student loan debt is not enough. The national average for medical record specialists is 35k a year while NM pays out 23k a year in a high cost of living city.

review_title: Amazing place to work and grow
job_title: Software Developer in Carol Stream, IL
pros: As a software developer, you have opportunities to work on many projects that make you expand your skill set. Really laid back place to work if you are in the IT department. Never work outside of my 9-5.
cons: Sometimes workload can get overwhelming and you will have to juggle multiple tasks at once.

review_title: Working experience in an institution lab
pros: You will have flexible working hours and normally no need to work overtime. Friendly colleagues. Get assessed to all university facilities while learning  at the same time.
cons: No promotion space. Everything outside is expensive because of the location in Chicago downtown. A nice choice for people wanting peaceful life but not those who are ambitious.

pros: Beautiful campus, good benefits, nice location
cons: NMH is a nice hospital but does not have patience for new hires working in a new department. A few weeks of training and you're put on the schedule with no room for error. If you make any mistakes at all they will fire you before your probation period and make you non rehireable

review_title: Neuro team/ stay away from dept
pros: Great benefits, nice hospital to work at, nice patients
cons: Too much favoritism in certain departments not all.  Some providers act superior towards other employees and patients.  Benefits, parking and daycare are over priced and enough to leave you living check to check. Managers have thousands of discrepancies they use against employees to make them feel lack of job security and trapped to do work that is out of job description.

review_title: My experience at Northwestern Hospital has been very rewarding.  l enjoy my co-workers, manager's and my team.
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: They have an excellent benefit and bonus package.  They cater to every specialty with several facilities to chose from and Northwestern Medicine Hospital is well known in Chicago.  They rank number 5 for best Hospital.
cons: It's not very easy to move around in the company to other departments that have opportunities.  Most times you have to be there at least 3 years before you can move on.

pros: Team is very willing to help. Management listens and is very understanding. Most people that do not do well here have poor work ethics. You need to know that this can be a demanding job and those who do not excel in their careers need to look at how they perform versus their peers.
cons: Advancement on some teams are not as fast as others.

pros: The professionalism and gold standard of excellence was great plus and really made it worth while working there. I thoroughly enjoyed working with my team and learning about all the exciting opportunities everyone else was working on.
cons: Perhaps a con would be the level of stuffiness there. Some people were very up tight but then again you could not interact with them if you did not wish to.

review_title: Zealous branding and marketing trumps quality of care.
pros: Location and co-workers.  Hospital looks like a hotel.
cons: Middle management is just a mouth piece for "senior leadership" and lack awareness of daily unit activities. They have no idea what occurs at the patient care level.

pros: Benefits, Union, Hotel Type Environment,  Over 80% of Nurses are of European descent.
cons: The name doesnt live up to the BRAND! Unsanitary" Pest Management " Roaches" Staff is nasty " nurses" leave a mess everywhere and unsafe conditions( hoodlums walking off the street going into pt rooms/stealing from them, poor management( lazy /unable to rectify simple computer issues),  arrogant physicians who endager the lives of others(trach pulled out of a stable pt and when covering up his mistake -attempted to reinsert the trach which cause more harm the pt /to returned back to the SICU post surgery,

pros: Great benefits and location.  Pretty friendly co-workers willing to help.  Mission to provide quality healthcare.
cons: Organization has grown from 2 to 10 hospitals through mergers over the last 5 years.  Rapid growth resulted in some rapid changes and stress.  Organization is still trying to find their footing amongst the different hospitals in different locations.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros: Commitment to employee engagement was once very important at NMHC. Organizational excellence and employee input  was welcomed and encouraged. Community involvement was valued.
cons: Very isolationist now - if you're not "upper management" you don't really matter anymore. There was a time when "C-suite" executives made it a point to connect with non-execs. Now, everyone is dispensable.

pros: Worked in IT. Good pay with a solid 401k. Generally flexible hours and some of the staff is a pleasure to work with.
cons: Everyone works in silos. Management is very poor, they often have self motivated plans or no plan at all. Nepotism is rampant. Aside from my direct manager, I never once felt like my career or goals were of any importance, I was a resource to be utilized when needed.

review_title: Environment of clinical austerity while the CEO makes a $15 million bonus
pros: Big hospital, high potential, great location
cons:
Housekeeping staff, pharmacists and others being cut down, cheap clinical care equipment and overall atmosphere of austerity, Meanwhile, the CEO made a $15 million bonus and made the cover of Crain's for these excesses. Initiatives of poor taste in order to try and artificially boost "patient satisfaction ratings." For example, Thank You cards being given to patients as they leave the hospital? The overall culture and safety culture is one of lip service.

This is a corporation folks, and a corporation is about making money, not caring for patients.

pros: The people you work with.  The matching retirement is above average.   There is an incentive program for departmental and facility goals.  The pay out each year is a marvelous benefit.  The properties and buildings are maintained with great care.
cons: Twelve hour days with salary intended for eight hours.  The highest level of leadership is focused strictly on money and protection of NM brand.

pros: Great location, new/latest technology, young community of nurses, and many specialties/floors to choose from
cons: Nurse to patient ratios are not great. 5:1, 6:1 night shift with no techs overnight to help staff and pay is slightly lower than other Chicago hospitals

pros: You can learn a lot working for this organization and the benefits are great.
cons: The politics is very high, not easy to move up even if you truly worked hard for it. Environment is kind of clickish and they will promote team work and tell you they love helping each other, but in reality they really don't want you ask them anything.

pros: Great co-workers-most were extremely helpful and there was a definite teamwork mentality.
cons: There was a definite imbalance between how nurses and CNA's were treated and treated each other. Many times CNA's would not help nurses or even complete their expected tasks and management never did anything about this when told. Also depending on what unit you worked on, nurses were almost always understaffed and overworked.

pros: It's so nice to work with fellow actors, and also to be helping shape the future of medicine. This job requires giving med students written feedback, and it has helped my writing skills immensely. I absolutely adore this job and I recommend it to all actors looking for a flexible job that pays pretty decently.
cons: Sometimes I wish I had more work, but it all depends on the type of standardized patients the med students need for their testing.

job_title: Applications Support Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Seems like there is plenty of opportunities and room for advancement. Getting the opportunity to train at epic for certification.
cons: Don't know what exactly my role is. A month in and still trying to figure out my exact duties on the job. Don't really have the direction or involvement from the management or leadership team.

pros: You can quit when you don't want to support discrimination. If you're white or just believe in combating foreign elements in our culture.
cons: Prejudice in hiring practices at the Chicago downtown location. I personally have know a hiring manager who confessed to me he and his fellow hiring managers screen out applicant resumes with foreign names first. before considering experience and skillset they are ensuring no one with strange names is hired. I was told they know this is illegal but they don't like regulation.

pros: As big as the hospital is, we are all usually met with similar positive attitudes: Patient’s First. Everyone here tries to satisfy the needs of our patients and goes beyond the call of duty to make an impact for them.
cons: As the hospital grows, keeping everyone on the same page becomes more difficult. It’s difficult to grow so much and keep the same caring atmosphere - but we manage to do it.

pros: Good experience, wide range of patients
cons: Low tuition reimbursement, high nurse to patient ratios, low budget, management does not engage in improving work conditions, high turnover with staff

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Chicago, IL
pros: Great atmosphere, team approach, good place to work as a new RN I imagine.
cons: Pay is the lowest in Chicago. Therefore there is constant turnover in RN staff.

review_title: I have been a nurse for over 20 years, and NMH was by far my favorite working experience.
job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Chicago, IL
pros: 12 hour shifts, great staff, newer facility, Starbucks in the lobby and cafeteria has terrific food. Patients are usually easy to work with.
cons: The hospital is a few blocks from the Magnificent Mile, so heavy traffic around campus. Also, you have to pay for parking, but NMH gives a discount.

review_title: Professional, Accommodating, Supportive of furthering your education
pros: Professional work environment, high standards, most people remember to treat others and behave like humans rather than robots.
cons: Raises are based on a generic performance review. This means an employee's job description may not apply to all grading criteria, which lessens their chance at a raise they may actually deserve.

pros: Colleagues, pathologists, opportunity to learn.
cons:
MANAGEMENT, Northwestern is top heavy with management. Sometimes managers have only 2 persons to manage.
So they go to meetings and try to justify their existence.

pros: Competitive pay for the area, annual bonuses,  slightly above average 401K benefits, a well-oiled machine.
cons: Very strict call-in policies, staffing could be better (but not the worst I have experienced).  Frequently required to work extra weekend days.

job_title: Customer Service Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Positive, customer oriented environment, dedicated to improving the well-being and quality of life of all their patients.
cons: Extraordinarily heavy "big corporation" environment, not conducive to patient care, individual initiative or innovation. Great disparity between highest and lowest salaries/wages. Vastly overblown salaries for upper level management.

review_title: Overall, good experience over the duration of my employment.  More good times than bad.
pros:
Great people to work with ~depending on the team that you were on
Great location to work with lots of transportation options
Very process oriented 
Excellent diversity program 
Very aggressive with funding projects throughout the organization
cons:
Management can be very cliquish
Hard to move up within the organization 
Very marginal pay increases

review_title: Ok company to work for, just not long term.
job_title: Patient Service Representative in Warrenville, IL
pros: Hours, Benefits, Pay, resources, fast paced
cons: Management, employees, hostile environment, micro management, frustration with new employees

review_title: Health and Fitness Centers: Upper Management is as shady as they come.
pros: Free membership, great (lower level) coworkers, awesome members/clients
cons: Where to begin, Upper management basis their decision making off friendships over qualifications; provides little to no explanation of any decisions; they don’t listen to any of their employees.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Lake Forest, IL
pros: They engage employees but never take the advice or implement changes that would help employees
cons:
No breaks during 12 hr shifts
Constant low staffing and asked to work overtime,
All the managers only care whether the patient is happy even if the nurse is doing her job well if the patient is not happy she will be in trouble, doesn’t make any sense, management is terrible

pros: Decent job with steady hours and kind coworkers. Great health benefits. You know your task every night and it's not too difficult to complete once you get the hang of it.
cons: Management seems to treat you as an afterthought compared to the sales department. The timing of pickups can be frustrating coordinating places with different deadlines.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lake Forest, IL
pros: Academic program with exposure to the forefront of medicine.  Excellent health care benefits.Enjoy working with many of my coworkers.
cons: Revolving door for hospitalists, intensivists, etc.  There is a lot of middle management.  I do not find it empowering.  Big medicine is everywhere.

pros: Great facility, top of the line equipment
cons: Below industry wages in radiology. This is why technologists leave. Techs at Northwestern earn well below competitive industry standards. Embarrassing that they treat dedicated hard workers this way when they could be compensated more fairly. Nurses just had a wage adjustment, why not radiology?

pros: Great reputation, high standards, pays well,
cons: You're always expendable, your end justifies their means.  MANAGEMENT keeps you in the dark.. and there is no one who truly takes your complaints as valid. HR and their onsite legal team will blackball you and make you sign things to keep you quiet.

job_title: Clinical Nurse/Registered Nurse in Chicago, IL
pros: Nice Looking Hospital with a youthful staff
cons: Low Pay, Terrible Company with Terrible Management. Okay for patients but Horrible for staff. Work for any other company, like Advocate, AMITA, etc... There's so many better hospitals in Illinois to work at.

pros: Financial stability has been sold for a decade. Regular meetings with leadership are appreciated. Understanding of competitive environment is strong.
cons: As with most organizations, there is some cultural dysfunction. Salaries have fallen well below market in some areas, sparking valuable experience to seek fair compensation elsewhere.

pros: Benefits have improved, great namesake, access to some of the best doctors.
cons: Advancing is POLITICAL and HR almost seems complicit, upper management lacks diversity (directors are almost always white males), many supervisors are incompetent and lack basic professionalism, if you work in billing you will be audited by people who have never done your job.  Everything about this organization screams corporation. Money and numbers are the only concern.

pros: The staff are great hardworking people.  Surgeons were excellent and very friendly.
cons: The hours were horrible. You might start as early as 6am one day then 10am the next. Forget about making after work appointments because there is no guarantee that you’ll get off in time.  Your hours are cut maybe working 30hrs in a week instead of 40. No consistency what so ever.  Some employees haven’t had a raise in years. They all seem miserable and are looking elsewhere for jobs.

review_title: Talent development for clinicians, technical, and operational employees and leaders.
pros: Flexibility,  collaborative, dynamic. The mission, "Northwrstern is an academic medical center where the patient comes first" is something to get behind and a guiding force for decision making
cons: Decision making can be very slow. There can be a lack of transparency regarding important and wide-sweeping changes to the organization. Leaders who message changes don't seem well informed or equipped to message change well.

review_title: Good for a year,  then move on.
pros: CE opportunities, autonomy (don't track productivity yet),  many coworkers to bounce treatment ideas against,  comprehensive orientation,  but makes you feel like a student again
cons: Low salary, no upward mobility,  management that does not care,  too budget conscious at the cost of patient care.  Lack of communication

pros: I feel really proud of our work here. Vacation time is fairly generous and easy to schedule, overtime is available, caring management.
cons: It's been hard to fill vacancies--we're hiring but not many applicants. Working long hours, every other weekend, not sure when we're going to get enough people hired.

review_title: Not bad until lay off time
pros: Good health benefits, awesome yearly bonus. Company discount perks.
cons: HR sucks. They are about 85-90% unhelpful with advancement. You must know someone to get in or ahead with this company. Northwestern cares more about the titles they hold vs. the people they help.

review_title: Not what you expect from a top 10 hospital system
pros:
Good Pay & Benefits
Overall employees want to do the best for the patients
cons:
Pretty chaotic organization with the Cadence Health merger
People feel overworked and there is a lack of resources to get things done
Low-morale among employees
Bureaucracy
Cronyism 
Lack of direction and communication from Senior Leadership

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Chicago, IL
pros: Room to grow, educational opportunities available. Benefits are good, a little pricey. Great 401K. Commuting is expensive but better then traffic!
cons: Leadership placing certain staff in roles that aren't appropriate. Styles of management not always conducive with what the needs are of the department. Turn over rate could be better, meaning lower.

job_title: Practice Operations Supervisor in Winfield, IL
pros: Majority of the employees are amazing and hard working people.  Teamwork is exceptional to give patients the best experience even in the most stressful of times.
cons: Short staffed is a way of life. Empty promises and constant change.

pros: Good for furthering your professional knowledge and skills. As an academic institution, following evidence-based medicine is important and there is an emphasis on teaching. Health insurance benefits are great.
cons: Employee satisfaction is not their focus. They barely give a competitive salary and certainly no added frills. It's all about making money and good patient reviews - at whatever cost.

review_title: Growing in Size, Declining in Quality
pros: Excellent 401k match. A great deal of flexibility for working from home or at other locations.
cons: As part of the non-clinical staff, other health systems are being acquired and integrated, and the quality of work has taken a backseat to deadlines.

review_title: Good place to work. People are ok depending what department you work in.
pros: Growth opportunity.  Pay good at least a few years ago. Things have changed a lot with pay and benefits and pension plan.
cons: Benefits have changed and pay if you are trying to get in now. Place has changed a lot.

review_title: Love working as an APN at NW
job_title: Advanced Practice Nurse in Oak Lawn, IL
pros:
Autonomy! Great name and professional environment. Big 10 school 
Complex patient population and conducive environment for learning 
Excellent teaching hospital
cons:
Salary needs to be more competitive 
Commute is very hard at times. Expensive to park. Downtown with many challenges. 
Not as much support from other professions for APN's

pros: Advance care for their patients, advance medical research with Northwestern University
cons: Management is unrealistic- not enough staff, too much is expected of employees, the company is growing so fast and they are not keeping up with the staffing needs. They don't learn from the mistakes of past mergers.

pros: I feel as if the administration really tries to take care of the employees. Regarding support, pay, benefits, staffing, etc. The culture is to help and take care of each other and the patients. I have worked at other places where you're sometimes by yourself. Here, your patient is everyone's and vice versa.
cons: Frequent meetings, but I think that might depend on what floor you are on.

pros: Generally top level equipment. Large hospital with lots of resources. Fairly good job security
cons: Frugal in some regards, doesn't pay at the upper end of the market. Can be a bit rigid in the way they do things, generally not very receptive to reassessing methods of doing things even when they've worked well at other top institutions.

pros: Benefits are really good. NMH being in the heart of the City offers a unique opportunity for those who work there to experience all that the City has to offer.
cons: Management is very rigid, and does not encourage innovation, creativity and growth.

review_title: Overall a good hospital to work for
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: great hospital to work for, location is wonderful, good cta acesscibility  people are very friendly.
cons: we have a new management model 4 managers for 1 unit you really don't know who is the go to person. I work on a patient care unit sometimes I am responsible for 15 patients on day shift.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Winfield, IL
pros: Nice hospital campus, minimal traffic during rush hour. Friendly staff and good food in the cafe and shops. Hopefully better now that CDH is part of northwestern
cons: Arrogant hospital management. Too good to be in the same room as their analysts. Long work hours due to poor IT systems and infrastructure.

pros: Easy working hours, no one holds you that accountable, pays well, easy to coast.
cons: No diversity, must do it the NM way or no other way, don't expect to move up unless you are a white male.

pros: Many front-line staff that care deeply for the patient, and go above and beyond.
cons: Little support for the front-line staff, paltry raises, top-heavy institution with enormous paychecks/raises.  Mergers with new hospitals create growth that is not sustainable with current staffing.

pros: All coworkers are very friendly. The doctors are great to work with. Centrally located in downtown Chicago. 2 blocks away from the beach. 1 block away from Michigan Avenue to do some shopping.
cons: Too much politics with some of the management, they do not recognize the employee for their hard work. Leader turnover is very high.

pros: Big healthcare to work for with options to transfer
cons: Pay in this dept is very low for it being northwestern in the city!!! Very busy dept and always short techs

pros:
-Strong financials, little risk of layoffs or downsizing
-Commitment to growth  means there's opportunities to transfer positions for clinicians
